Award.AbstractNarration:
Recognizing and discriminating among faces and objects is a critical human ability, particularly for jobs that require highly specialized visual skills such as in forensics, medical imaging, and homeland security. Recent research suggests that there is vast individual variability among people in their perceptual abilities, including the ability to recognize faces and non-face objects. However, people are poor at predicting their perceptual abilities relative to others, making it difficult to capitalize on this variability. This project applies a psychometric approach to the study of individual differences in perceptual abilities. From a theoretical perspective, studying these individual differences provides a new avenue for understanding mechanisms underlying visual perception. Practically speaking, these tools can identify individuals with the greatest aptitude for work that demands specific visual skills, such as baggage screening, satellite imagery analysis, and radiology. Creating and validating reliable psychometric tools in high-level vision can be useful to basic and applied science, education, and industry. Some jobs require hundreds of perceptual decisions each day, and some organizations rely on combining perceptual decisions from many individuals. The ability to predict even a small amount of variance between people could culminate in improved accuracy, increased efficiency, and decreased cost.

This project focuses on holistic processing, a visual strategy associated with face recognition, but also with other examples of expert perception. This project will exend recent efforts to measure individual differences in holistic processing by creating and testing measures that will enable the researchers to address questions about individual differences in holistic processing in a reliable manner. The project will then explore the construct validity of holistic processing using these measures to address several questions: Is holistic face processing related to domain-general abilities? How is holistic processing related to face recognition ability? How are these relationships mediated by learning that may occur within a test? Finally, experiments will focus on the interplay between domain-general and domain-specific factors during the acquisition of holistic processing, asking whether holistic processing correlates across domains, and as a function of training experiences. This represents a bridge between experimental work on the mechanisms of acquisition of holistic processing and an individual differences approach. These studies will help determine whether there is one or several possible causes of holistic processing effects, and how to choose a training method on the basis of basic cognitive measures to achieve a given training outcome. Thus, this project will combine correlational and experimental methods to establish the validity of holistic processing and elucidate its role in the network of relationships within which it operates.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research was designed to investigate holistic processing, a visual strategy associated with face recognition, but also with other cases of expert perception. We asked how holistic processing develops and what determines who processes objects using this strategy. This project took a novel approach to this question, by using methods that are typically not used in vision but have been used to study individual differences in personality or intelligence. To put it simply, many questions about how and why people vary in how they perceive objects have never been addressed because we lacked tools to measure visual abilities. As such, the first contribution of this project has been the development of stimuli and tests designed to be sensitive to the differences in ability and strategy used by people in the normal population when they perceive faces or other complex objects. These tests have been made available to other scientists and will allow future research in ways that were not possible before we these tests existed. This research program culminated in at least 10 scientific publications, with two more additional studies currently under peer review, and a number of continuing lines of research that will continue to address these questions.  

In our work, we have discovered that people vary a great deal in their ability to recognize objects visually, and that this ability is not predicted by general intelligence. This is important, because it suggests that some skills, such as those involved in medical diagnosis or forensic analysis, may depend on abilities that are not currently being measured. As a case study, we demonstrated that over and beyond differences in intelligence and in training, this visual ability was predictive of performance detecting tumors in chest radiographs. We have demonstrated that holistic processing is not a strategy unique to face recognition, but that it depends on the amount of experience observers have with objects of a category. People start demonstrating holistic effects after just a few hours of experience, and 10 hours of training leads to effects that are almost as large as those obtained for faces. Aside from differences that occur with only a few hours of experience, we also have studies the effect of large differences in one?s environment, as we explored the role of hometown population density on face recognition abilities. We found that hometown population density mainly affected men, with men from larger hometowns performing better than those from smaller hometowns. This work shows how understanding experience in the real world may require more than a quantification of the environment. Men and women growing up in the same environment likely have different experiences, which can modulate effects on visual abilities.

Further, this previous research has led to a number of new ideas and new questions. For instance, what role does configuration of visual features have in other domains of real-word expertise? For instance, how does learning to read music affect our visual perception? In particular, we found that even though music readers never explicitly learn or practice to distinguish notes that are correctly configured (dot and stem joined like p and d, rather than like a b and q), they are highly sensitive to such dot-stem configuration. This finding will help psychologists design more controlled studies of expert music reading, so that we can better understand how musical education affects our visual perception.

Finally, this research has provided a wealth of professional development opportunities, including for graduate students moving on to independent research careers, and for undergraduate research assistants learning skills that will serve them in their own professional development (this includes individuals from groups under-represented in science, such as women and African Americans). The PI also participated in the School for Science and Math at Vanderbilt, a program that offers local public high school students a 4-year research experience.
